Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Role of Health in Shaping Zoning Policy Decisions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study examines the political, legal, and pragmatic considerations in addressing health issues via zoning policy. The investigators aim to address 1) whether, how, and in what contexts the language, mapping, and process of zoning can address contemporary health concerns; 2) the role health considerations play in zoning policy makers' decisions; and 3) the consequences of efforts to include provisions that address health in a comprehensive zoning rewrite . These aims will be addressed through an ethnographic case study of TransForm Baltimore, the City's first comprehensive zoning rewrite since 1971. Interviews will be conducted with developers, local decision makers, and experts on land use policy and law, environmental justice, and healthy city design. The project will also include an examination of comparable zoning issues in New Zealand to serve as a point of comparison.

While research has shown that the built environment influences health outcomes, little discussion addresses how those involved in shaping land use policy understand the connection between land use and health. Given that the original purpose of zoning was to promote "health, security, morals or general welfare," scant data exist on whether and why "promoting health" functions as a guiding principle. This research aims to understand the inner workings of the rezoning process, whether zoning is viewed as a means to address social problems, how stakeholders respond to proposed health-promoting measures, and if tools or processes can be developed to ensure that zoning decisions address health concerns wisely and fairly.

Contributing to discussions of the relative influence of governance, innovation and power when changing urban settings, particularly those that face shrinking population levels and sizable health disparities is a central goal of this work. Finally, this study intends to produce considerations for what an equitable use of zoning as a police power might entail and address the limitations of employing a regulatory process like zoning to combat the complex factors that create health disparities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Zoning codes regulate how private land is used, in part to “promote health and welfare.”   For the first time in 40 years, Baltimore City is comprehensively rewriting its zoning code. This dissertation research focused on describing and evaluating the process of Baltimore's zoning rewrite and the opportunities and challenges this process posed for promoting health. I assessed how those participating in the rewrite and the presence of competing land use problems affected the role of health in the rewrite. The findings result from over two years of data from participant-observation of public, open and staff-level zoning rewrite meetings; interviews with key rewrite participants; and evaluations of multiple drafts of the zoning code for potential health impacts.

Zoning ordinances regulate land use elements such as housing density and type, proximity of retail to residential areas, location of liquor stores, parking requirements, and landscaping. These factors can directly and indirectly impact housing affordability, residential segregation, food access, walkability, crime, and air quality. Despite these links, public health researchers are often not involved in shaping these legal tools. Little peer-reviewed research details the fate of health recommendations presented in a zoning process and what factors promote or hinder the inclusion of these considerations. My research addressed this gap.

Many opportunities exist for promoting health through zoning. Health, however, was neither explicitly nor implicitly included in the initial rewrite goals. Many participants did not recognize the links between zoning and health. “Health” in the context of zoning was often operationalized narrowly (e.g. preventing overcrowding and limiting the spread of fire). Little attention was given to cumulative impacts of land uses on vulnerable populations.  Key decision makers were uncertain about the legal grounds for promoting health in zoning codes in general, and particularly around expanding healthy food access and limiting concentration of liquor outlets. Representatives from the Department of Health were not initially invited to the main rewrite advisory group. While efforts were made to include a variety of participants from a variety of neighborhoods, 90% of the participants in public meetings were white. This presence 1) was notable as 67% of Baltimore City's population is black and 2) raised questions about the range of needs represented in this city-wide endeavor. One outcome of this participation, while not necessarily unusual, was a greater focus on the needs of more affluent and stable areas of town than those of less-stable areas.

Involvement from public health researchers and advocates was able to increase the discussion of health-relevant topics and add health considerations to the zoning agenda.  Public health participation provided an opportunity to raise unique concerns about the potential impacts of zoning on health, particularly for vulnerable populations. Further, it provided a means for explaining links between zoning practice and health relevant outcomes, especially in terms of off premise liquor outlets and crime.  Including a public health voice, however, required a significant expenditure of resources. Such participation depended on volunteer efforts and grant funding. These resources stood in contrast to the financial and political capital of those such as developers and business leaders whose professional duties required involvement and familiarity with the rewrite.
